awd_titl_txt: Transitions: Rational design of viral vectors
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to use genetic data to accurately predict the attributes of living organisms would have a profound impact on many fields of biology, including genetics, molecular biology, synthetic biology and biomedical engineering.  One goal of this project is to develop approaches for genotype-phenotype predictions using a simple viral system (Vesicular Stomatitis Virus).  Additional project goals are to allow the PI, who is a well-respected computational biologist, to gain hands-on experience using several crucial experimental techniques and to establish a research program that has experience in both experimentation and modeling. This project will also provide research opportunities for many undergraduate and graduate students, including students from underrepresented groups.     

The overall goal of the project is to build a multiscale model showing how fluctuations of discrete events at the molecular level determine the quantitative virulence of a virus population. This model will be developed as a genotype to phenotype map that captures the relationships between genotype and phenotype observed in a library of 9,600 engineered vesicular stomatitis virus variants. This model will establish how the genetic control of the transcription and translation of the vesicular stomatitis virus five genes can determine viral propagation in cell culture without introducing mutations that alter the function of the proteins coded by the viral genome. The model derived from experimental data will guide the design of optimized vectors that combine a low-virulence and a high-degree of reproducibility. The project will proceed through iterations of the Design-Build-Test-Learn cycle that will allow the characterization of 96 virus variants per month by the end of the performance period. Libraries of virus variants will be designed and assembled before being transfected in cell cultures. They will be tested by flow cytometry. Experimental data will be used to refine the mathematical model of viral replication by adding new data to that collected in previous iterations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit
Viruses are fascinating entities, and some of them, like the Vesicular Stomatitis Virus (VSV), have proven to be incredibly useful for scientific research. VSV has been used to develop vaccines for dangerous viruses such as Ebola, which are too risky to grow in large quantities. Scientists are also exploring how VSV can be engineered to target and kill cancer cells, offering a potential breakthrough in cancer treatment.


To better understand how VSV works, researchers created a detailed mathematical model. This model simulates how the virus enters a host cell, makes copies of itself, and then spreads to other cells. What makes this model special is that it incorporates the natural randomness of these processes, meaning it can predict why infections might behave differently in different situations.


The model provided surprising insights. For example, it helped explain experimental results where scientists had shuffled the order of genes in the virus's genome. Using the model, researchers could simulate all the possible ways the virus’s genes could be rearranged. These simulations suggested that some rearrangements might make the virus better to develop biomedical applications. By extending the model further, scientists proposed a new way that the virus might copy its genome—a process that is shared by other significant viruses, including Ebola, Rabies, and Mumps.


To test these predictions, the research team developed automated processes to produce large numbers of DNA molecules. They also built a state-of-the-art laboratory equipped with the necessary safety features to handle live VSV safely. In this lab, they established methods to grow and maintain cells, insert viral DNA into the cells to produce engineered viruses, and observe how the virus spreads within individual cells. This combination of advanced modeling and hands-on experimentation has opened new doors for understanding how VSV and similar viruses function, strategies natural selection could use to evolve the viruses, and approaches biomedical engineers could use to leverage the virus’s ability to infect cells to deliver life-saving genetic medicines.


Broader Impacts
This research project didn’t just expand scientific knowledge—it also had a significant impact on education, training, and the broader scientific community. The Principal Investigator (PI), who led the project was able to align his research program with the graduate classes he teaches. This hands-on experience with mammalian cells and virus engineering enriched his teaching, making it more relevant for students to learn about cutting-edge methods used to produce modern medicines, such as vaccines, antibodies, and gene therapies.


The project also provided valuable training opportunities for students. Eight undergraduate students studying both engineering and life sciences participated in the research. They learned how to use advanced laboratory equipment and gained practical skills that will help them in their future careers. Many of these students were from underrepresented groups in science, including first-generation college students and students from minority backgrounds. Four graduate students specializing in areas like biology, chemical engineering, and biomedical engineering also contributed their expertise to the project.


Beyond education, the project improved the research infrastructure at the institution. The data collected during this study helped secure additional funding for automated equipment, which now makes experiments faster and more efficient. This new equipment not only benefits the PI lab but is also available to other researchers, enabling them to explore new scientific questions.

Finally, the tools and knowledge developed in this project are being used to launch new research initiatives. For example, the team is now working on innovative vaccine technologies and viruses designed to treat melanoma, a type of skin cancer. These projects could lead to groundbreaking treatments and further demonstrate how fundamental research, research infrastructures, and education can lead to real-world applications.
